column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=The order of the procession was as follows : —
#Text=Montmorency , carrying a stick .
#Text=Two disreputable-looking curs , friends of Montmorency ’s .
#Text=George , carrying coats and rugs , and smoking a short pipe .
#Text=Harris , trying to walk with easy grace , while carrying a bulged-out Gladstone bag in one hand and a bottle of lime-juice in the other .
#Text=Greengrocer ’s boy and baker ’s boy , with baskets .
#Text=Boots from the hotel , carrying hamper .
#Text=Confectioner ’s boy , with basket .
#Text=Grocer ’s boy , with basket .
#Text=Long-haired dog .
#Text=Cheesemonger ’s boy , with basket .
#Text=Odd man carrying a bag .
#Text=Bosom companion of odd man , with his hands in his pockets , smoking a short clay .
#Text=Fruiterer ’s boy , with basket .
#Text=Myself , carrying three hats and a pair of boots , and trying to look as if I did n’t know it .
#Text=Six small boys , and four stray dogs .
#Text=When we got down to the landing-stage , the boatman said :
#Text=“ Let me see , sir ; was yours a steam-launch or a house-boat ? ”
#Text=[ Picture : The bring of the provisions ]
#Text=On our informing him it was a double-sculling skiff , he seemed surprised .
#Text=We had a good deal of trouble with steam launches that morning .
#Text=It was just before the Henley week , and they were going up in large numbers ; some by themselves , some towing houseboats .
#Text=I do hate steam launches : I suppose every rowing man does .
#Text=I never see a steam launch but I feel I should like to lure it to a lonely part of the river , and there , in the silence and the solitude , strangle it .

#Text=There is a blatant bumptiousness about a steam launch that has the knack of rousing every evil instinct in my nature , and I yearn for the good old days , when you could go about and tell people what you thought of them with a hatchet and a bow and arrows .

#Text=The expression on the face of the man who , with his hands in his pockets , stands by the stern , smoking a cigar , is sufficient to excuse a breach of the peace by itself ; and the lordly whistle for you to get out of the way would , I am confident , ensure a verdict of “ justifiable homicide ” from any jury of river men .
#Text=They used to have to whistle for us to get out of their way .

#Text=If I may do so , without appearing boastful , I think I can honestly say that our one small boat , during that week , caused more annoyance and delay and aggravation to the steam launches that we came across than all the other craft on the river put together .
#Text=“ Steam launch , coming ! ” one of us would cry out , on sighting the enemy in the distance ; and , in an instant , everything was got ready to receive her .
#Text=I would take the lines , and Harris and George would sit down beside me , all of us with our backs to the launch , and the boat would drift out quietly into mid-stream .
#Text=On would come the launch , whistling , and on we would go , drifting .

#Text=At about a hundred yards off , she would start whistling like mad , and the people would come and lean over the side , and roar at us ; but we never heard them ! Harris would be telling us an anecdote about his mother , and George and I would not have missed a word of it for worlds .

#Text=Then that launch would give one final shriek of a whistle that would nearly burst the boiler , and she would reverse her engines , and blow off steam , and swing round and get aground ; everyone on board of it would rush to the bow and yell at us , and the people on the bank would stand and shout to us , and all the other passing boats would stop and join in , till the whole river for miles up and down was in a state of frantic commotion .
#Text=And then Harris would break off in the most interesting part of his narrative , and look up with mild surprise , and say to George :
#Text=“ Why , George , bless me , if here is n’t a steam launch ! ”
#Text=And George would answer :
#Text=“ Well , do you know , I thought I heard something ! ”
#Text=Upon which we would get nervous and confused , and not know how to get the boat out of the way , and the people in the launch would crowd round and instruct us :
#Text=“ Pull your right — you , you idiot ! back with your left .
#Text=No , not you — the other one — leave the lines alone , ca n’t you — now , both together .
#Text=NOT that way .
#Text=Oh , you — ! ”

#Text=Then they would lower a boat and come to our assistance ; and , after quarter of an hour ’s effort , would get us clean out of their way , so that they could go on ; and we would thank them so much , and ask them to give us a tow .
#Text=But they never would .

#Text=Another good way we discovered of irritating the aristocratic type of steam launch , was to mistake them for a beanfeast , and ask them if they were Messrs. Cubit ’s lot or the Bermondsey Good Templars , and could they lend us a saucepan .
#Text=Old ladies , not accustomed to the river , are always intensely nervous of steam launches .
#Text=I remember going up once from Staines to Windsor — a stretch of water peculiarly rich in these mechanical monstrosities — with a party containing three ladies of this description .
#Text=It was very exciting .
#Text=At the first glimpse of every steam launch that came in view , they insisted on landing and sitting down on the bank until it was out of sight again .
#Text=They said they were very sorry , but that they owed it to their families not to be fool-hardy .
